Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Investigating Geochemical Signatures in Greenland Ice of a Possible Extraterrestrial Impact During the Younger Dryas Climate Event
Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary objective of the proposed research is to obtain records of platinum, iridium, and osmium concentrations and osmium isotope ratios in the GISP2 Greenland ice core in order to investigate the hypothesis that there was a meteorite or comet impact at the onset of the Younger Dryas abrupt climate event 12,900 years ago. These analyses will be combined with high-resolution measurements of climate proxies obtained on the same samples. Osmium isotopes have the potential not only to conclusively confirm or refute the presence of an extraterrestrial impact, but also to provide information about the size and type of the impactor, should one be confirmed. High-resolution analyses of the atmospheric circulation proxies sodium, calcium, and iron represent a leap in ice core analysis resolution from one sample per three years to over 100 samples per year. The proposed research activities would contribute towards an understanding of what happened at the Younger Dryas, which will be of broad interest to geologists, geochemists, climatologists, archeologists, astronomers, and the general public.

Following recent reports of a large anomaly in platinum concentration in the GISP2 ice core, four investigators propose a series of collaborative analyses at Dartmouth College and the University of Maine on GISP2 ice core samples of Younger Dryas age to: (1) evaluate the platinum spike at the Younger Dryas onset for potential contamination and contributions from volcanic and terrestrial sources, (2) measure osmium concentration and isotope composition to evaluate whether an impact occurred at the Younger Dryas onset and assess the nature of any impactor, and (3) assess the environmental change across this critical climate transition by measuring iron, sodium and calcium at storm-scale resolution using a new laser ablation mass-spectrometry system. The proposed research will provide students with opportunities for engaged learning in order to increase their interest and knowledge of how geochemical investigations provide insights to climate change affecting the Arctic. In particular, this study will constitute a major portion of a Ph.D. thesis and an undergraduate Senior Thesis. It will expose graduate and undergraduate students to cutting-edge geochemical and mass spectrometric techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Problem & Motivation. The Younger Dryas (YD) event represents a major cooling interlude during the last deglaciation between 12,900 and 11,600 years. The abrupt onset of this event appears to have coincided with the Pleistocene megafaunal extinction in North America and Europe and Clovis Paleoindian cultural modifications and population declines.  For the last eleven years numerous papers have documented evidence for a Younger Dryas extraterrestrial impact including microspherules, nanodiamonds, magnetic grains, and glass-like carbon, although the hypothesis remains controversial. The discovery of a large Pt anomaly at the onset of Younger Dryas in a Greenland ice-core (GISP2) (Petaev et al., 2013) with a Pt/Ir ratio of ~1200 has been interpreted as the signature of an impact by a geochemically unusual iron meteorite (Sikhote-Alin type). While it is difficult to find terrestrial material with this geochemical fingerprint, extraterrestrial material with such a high Pt/Ir has likewise not been documented. Thus, the interpretation of a meteoritic source for the GISP2 Pt anomaly is based on circumstantial evidence.

Objectives and samples. The overall objective of this project was to determine platinum metals concentrations and Os isotope composition variations across the Ållerød-Younger Dryas transition in a Greenland ice-core. As the extraterrestrial Os isotope signatures provide a unique fingerprint we expected to settle the question of whether or not there was a meteorite impact at the onset of Younger Dryas. The project was technically very challenging as the expected Os background concentration of ice is of the order of 1 femto-gram per gram of ice (1 fg of Os = 3 million atoms of Os) or less. The anomalous Os enrichment resulting from Sikhote-Alin type of meteorite (Petaev et al., 2013) should be on the order of 600 fg/g. Working with Sungmin Hong (Korea) and J.P. Steffensen (Denmark) we obtained data on GRIP ice-core from Greenland.

Major Outcomes.

1. Development of ultra-low level Os isotope measurements. During the period of this grant we developed robust techniques to precisely measure Os and its isotopes using Negative-Thermal Ionization Mass Spectrometry in 25-50 g samples of ice (~ 10 fg to 25 fg of total Os measured; details published in Seo et al., 2018, Analytical Chemistry, DOI: 10.1021/acs.analchem.8b00150).

2. Development of procedure to separate other platinum metals after Os has been removed. New Os separation procedures have been developed so that other platinum group elements (Ru, Pd, Ir, and Pt) could also be separated from the same sample aliquot and their concentrations determined using isotope dilution. This has been necessary given that the ice-core samples are precious and only a limited amount of sample is available. Using a triple quadrupole ICP-MS instrument (ICP-QQQ) that uses reaction cell technology instrument we have developed highly sensitive protocols to measure Ru, Pd, Ir, and Pt isotope ratios. However, we find that a key chemical (ultrapure hydrogen peroxide) contains high amounts of Pt, Ir, Ru and Pd and cannot be cleaned by any procedure! Consequently our Os-PGE separation procedure has allowed us to successfully measure only those GRIP samples that display spikes in Os concentrations.

3. Osmium concentration and isotope composition of Greenland ice-core (GRIP). We investigated the critical time period spanning about 100 years transitioning from Allerod to Younger Dryas. We find that the transition begins with a large plinian eruption (Laacher See, Germany) and the climate starts to deteriorate. The Laacher See eruption may have occurred in at least three phases spread over about 15 years. Two earlier pulses of eruption that we identified are associated with high peaks in Os and Pt (#6 and #7). The Os isotope composition unequivocally points to a magmatic and not an extra-terrestrial contribution. Significantly, we did not find any increase in Os at the time period (#3) where a large Pt peak was found by Peteav et al (2013). In fact the corresponding 187Os/188Os ratios are unremarkable. However, most intriguingly, the Younger Dryas Transition ends with a sharp decline in d18O just after #1, which marks the time (2.5 years or less) when the Os isotope composition and concentration of ice indicate a 5 fold increase in the accretion of extra-terrestrial material, with respect to present day. If this represents a global increase in extra-terrestrial Os it would indicate a meteorite impact just before the onset of Younger Dryas. If that meteorite was a carbonaceous chondrite its size would be about 70m. Such a meteorite would release an energy of up to 10-50 megatons of exploding TNT. These observations suggest a double-whammy of volcanism and meteorite impact may be involved in the Younger Dryas abrupt cooling.
